Number and type of infrastructure projects implemented; number of training events conducted and number of people trained across the various sectors by the project; food crop productivity and diversification; farm and off-farm income level; mobile phone connectivity across the district.

comment.narrative: At the time of the start of project implementation in 2008, there was only 3 primary health clinics in the entire district; no health center; large section of the district has no primary health facilities; 31 primary school buildings with at least 50% using makeshift structures; no high school; only about 10% of all instructional staff members hold teacher training certificates and on government payroll; no science laboratories on any school; no concrete bridges in any part of the district; no lighting in the clinics; only about 20% of all hand pumps constructed were functioning; few community water and sanitation management committees but not functioning; food crop production - rice, cassava, fruits and vegetables - are extremely low to the point that most of the food requirements are met through import from other districts and counties; and wealth community participation and local governance .

title.narrative: Enhancing Resilience of Vulnerable Coastal Areas

description.narrative: Protect vulnerable coastal lands and provide job opportunities for communities dwellers that leads to sustainable livelihoods and protection of the environment for inclusive economic growth

LDCF funds will first create a national level enabling environment that is favorable to adaptation in coastal communities across Liberia. LDCF funds will also develop targeted capacity in three counties that are suffering the effects of climate change.

The Objective of the project is ‘to reduce vulnerability and build resilience of local communities and socio-economic sectors to the threats of climate change in Liberia’s coastal areas. The indicators for achieving this are: 1. Level of follow-up investment into large-scale, coastal protection projects; and 2. Number of people with improved living conditions and not subject to climate change impacts

comment.narrative: Very limited information on sea levels and coastal erosion due to lack of trained personnel and forecasting equipment in Liberia
One high level consultation on coastal erosion lesson held and report available. Four energy efficient stoves constructed and officially turned over by CD of UNDP to the community; report available.

title.narrative: Strengthen Lib Capability to provide climate info & Serv

description.narrative: It will support current climate monitoring and Early Warning Systems in Liberia so as to increase adaptive capacity of local communities and sectors.
Strengthen climate monitoring and Early Warning Systems in Liberia to increase adaptive capacity of local communities and sectors.

-Number of communication channels operational to disseminate climate-related early warnings. -Percentage of population in within the target districts with access to improved climate-related flood, storm and coastal surge early warnings (disaggregated by gender). -Development frameworks that integrate climate information in the formulation.

comment.narrative: -At present, information is relayed to communities mostly via word-of-mouth, but without the structure of SOPs. -To be confirmed through Activity 2.3.1 of the LDCF (% men and % women) – presumed to be 0% men and 0% women. -The Poverty Reduction Strategy (2008-2011) is the current national over-arching development framework, and does not mention climate change.

description.narrative: To strengthen Liberia’s climate-related monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change.

1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard.
2. Domestic finance committed to Meteorology Department, Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

comment.narrative:
1. Average capacity scorecard rating of 57 across men and women (see Annex 5).
2. Annual budget of US$ 64,480 allocated to Meteorology Department; annual budget of US$ 276,877 allocated to Hydrological Services; and annual budget of US$50,000 allocated to NDRC.

1. Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 134 for both men and women (see Annex 5).
2. 20% increase in annual domestic finance allocated to Meteorology Department, Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

Under the reporting period, there has been no increase in domestic finance to monitor and warn against climate hazards. However, we are optimistic that the awareness being generated about the importance of early warnings for the operations of different sectors and when alerts and warnings begin to be issued from the EWS Project and National Meteorological and Hydrological Services (NMHS), all this will prove the need for public finance and financing from private sources, such as the sales of weather products. The first year of implementation has been mired by the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease which slowed down several aspects of implementation, especially field-based activities and those involving collaboration with partners and external consultants.

description.narrative: Increased capacity of hydro-meteorological services and associated networks to monitor and predict extreme weather, climate-related hazards and climate trends.

1. Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network (fully operational).
2. Frequency of data transmission.
3. Number of sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced using improved information.

comment.narrative:
1. AWS: 0%
Hydrometric stations: 0%.
2. At present, the 1 AWS transmits data at the synoptic hours of (GMT) 06h00, 09h00, 12h00, 15h00, 18h00 and 00h00, although not consistently.
3. At present, the only sector-specific information produced is for the aviation sector.

1. AWS: 100% (at least 9 AWSs).
Hyrdometric: 100% (at least 6 stations).
2. 18 AWSs and hydrometric stations (11 new AWSs, 1 rehabilitated AWS, 6 hydrometric stations), transmitting continuously.
3. Sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced for three of the following: agriculture, water, aviation, fisheries/coastal water users, health, tourism, construction, energy and road, rail and sea transport.

Core activities around this output could not be implemented due to the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) and the subsequent delays in the procurement of equipment and services. The Government of Liberia requested UNDP to procure equipment along with services like training, installation and maintenance. Because of the low level of human capital, we feel that the procurement of equipment alone cannot guarantee EWS for Liberia and its long term sustainability. The long term agreement (LTA) to be issued by CIRDA is the best option for the country. The EVD also hampered other capacity building activities as experts could not come into the country and staff could not be accepted in several countries for training. In 2014, negotiations with the World Meteorological Organization Training Institutions in Nigeria and Kenya collapsed because of the EVD, but responses from both countries are advanced and students will be sent over by 4th quarter. Probably the most substantive deliverable for the year, besides training, will be the renovation of the building to be used as the National Meteorological Center (NMC) within the premises of the Roberts International Airport. This project is to begin during the 4th quarter.

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of tailored climate, environmental and socio-economic data to produce appropriate information which can be communicated to government entities and communities to enable informed decision-making.

1. Number of communication channels operational to disseminate climate-related early warnings.
2. Percentage of population within the two targeted districts that has access to improved climate-related flood, storm and coastal surge warnings (disaggregated by gender).

comment.narrative:
1. At present, information is relayed to communities mostly via word-of-mouth, but without the structure of SOPs.
2. 0% of men
0 % of women.

1. At least 3 of the following: radio, television, print media (newspapers, flyers), word-of-mouth and mobile phone communication channels are operational.
2. 100 % of men
100 % of women.
These activities were delayed until equipment is procured, deployed and climate information is generated to be communicated to target users. There is no product to communicate at this stage.

description.narrative: Increased awareness in government, private sector and local communities of the major risks associated with climate change, and use of available information when formulating development policies and strategies.
1. Development frameworks that integrate climate information in their formulation.

comment.narrative: 1. The Agenda for Transformation (2012-2017) highlights the need to develop climate change mainstreaming and response strategies, but does not emphasize the need for improved information to inform the strategies.
1. At least updated Agenda for Transformation (to be revised in 2017) to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period.

The ongoing collaboration with the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning around the EWS Project implementation and other fora organized by other NAPA and National Projects as well as the UNDP will guarantee an entry point for the revision of the AfT when the time comes. The MFDP leads the process of developing the Nation's development agenda and is a member of the Project Steering Committee. The EWS is making inputs into the development of the National Adaptation Plan (NAP) for Liberia and is poised to integrate climate information into national and sectorial plans.

title.narrative: Strengthen Transparency, Accountability, Oversight and P

description.narrative: STAOP aims to support strengthening governance and promoting transparency and accountability.

The project aims to strengthen corruption prevention, transparency and accountability and provide support to both state institutions and civil society organizations to increase transparency and accountability in governance processes
independent political entity
Anti corruption

Indicators: -Increased levels of dialogue at the national and local level on strategies to improve transparency and accountability -No. of initiatives between oversight institutions and line ministries to improve transparency and accountability
Indicators: -Procedural and performance standards established , based on the findings of risk assessments and audits -Increased efficiency in financial management and service delivery -Increased levels of access to information to official data
Indicators •Procedural and performance standards established , based on the findings of audits -Improved capacity to manage development funds and deliver services
Indicator: -Increased access to information on concessions and revenues generated -No. of Public hearing of LEITI reports in the catchment area of concessionaries institutionalized -Extent of Civil society (including women and youth organizations) and media engagement in providing information on all aspects of the industry in an easily-accessible format to the public
Indicator: -Increased knowledge of UNCAC and the UNCAC self-assessment process -Increased coordination and networking between oversight institutions, ministries and agencies, civil society and media around UNCAC -Measures taken to address gaps identified through the self-assessment processes
Indicators: -Increased capacity of LACC -Level of investigative independence of LACC (both proactive and reactive detection -Increased public perception of LACC’s capability to address corruption
Indicators: -Existence of participatory initiatives (involving women and youth) to promote transparency and accountability at national and local level, particularly in service delivery -Increased levels of access to information -Increased coverage of media on transparency and accountability -Increased coverage of media on transparency and accountability with women and youth specific messages

comment.narrative:
Baseline: high awareness of corruption issues but limited dialogue and engagement on prevention, transparency and accountability
Baseline: -varying levels of prevention measures adopted in line ministries -limited data on efficiency in service delivery and financial management in line ministries and agencies, and on service delivery -Corruption risk in the Education sector assessed.
Baseline: •lack of internal control in county administration (based on 2010 audit report) •limited capacity to manage development funds and deliver services
Baseline: -Lack of consolidated information on concessions awarded, revenues generated and invested and environmental and social impact of extractive industry and natural resource sector - limited compliance of concessionaries to requirements of EITI reporting - limited knowledge and confidence of general public in the LEITI process
Baseline: -Limited awareness of UNCAC and opportunities presented by UNCAC to support anti-corruption reforms
Baseline: -Limited capacity of LACC to investigate and prosecute corruption cases. -Investigation rates of LACC caseload is only nine percent
Baseline: -Emerging capacity of Civil society and community based organizations to monitor service delivery -Lack of information on services provided at the local level - Limited capacity of CSOs and media to monitor service delivery

-UNCAC self-assessment conducted to identify gaps and action plan developed - capacity assessment of LACC and MoJ prosecutorial capacity undertaken and capacity plan developed - Integrity clubs in 5 schools in Monsterado established. -Capacity development plan developed specifically for increasing prosecutorial capacity

title.narrative: Strengthening National Capacities for Dev Effective

title.narrative: Strengthening National Capacities for Dev Effective
Strengthening National Capacities for Dev Effective

description.narrative: Strengthening National Capacities for Dev Effective
policy, planning and administration

Output 1: Indicator 1.1: Rate of financial reporting requirement compliance. Indicator 1.2: # of Finance staff enrolled for accounting certification with 25% women representation Indicator 1.3: # of MACs Procurement staff undertake hands-on training and CIPS Level 2 certification with 25% women representation Indicator 1.4: Online M&E national database portal # of M&E plans # of M&E reports uploaded on database # of sector projects Indicator: 1.5: # of M&E manuals printed and distributed Indicator 1.6: Curriculum on short-term National Implementation (NIM) training developed
Output 2: Indicator 2.1: % of projects completed aligned to AfT Indicator 2.2: # of Private sector constituency engagement meetings # of civil society constituency engagement meetings Indicator 2.3: National NGO Policy Indicator 2:4: Revised NGO database and with up-to date information Indicator 2.5: # of training on Donor engagement & Mgt conducted with at least 20% women
Output 4: Indicator 4.1: # of staff with technical skills in respective functional area Indictor4.2: # of LRA Medium Term (3-5 years) IT Strategy developed and being adhere to # of servers for Data Center being constructed at LRA HQ # of industrial copiers to effectuate enhanced IT service delivery # of vehicle to facilitate mobility of IT team between HQ, sector ministries and Tax and Customs Business Offices
Output 5: Indicator 5.1: # Social-economic report Indicator 5.2: # Economic Journals published
Output 6: Indicators 6: # of “special media platforms supported # of communication and knowledge products produced and disseminated # of Media stories # of quarterly progress reports Annual report

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Baseline: (2014) Gaps identified in micro-assessment for program implementation, financial reporting and procurement capacities of 40 MAC
Baseline: (2014) 36 MACs Finance Staff started training on ATSWA/CPA at LIPA coordinated by LICPA
Baseline: (2014) Gaps identified in micro-assessment for procurement certification capacities of 40 MACs.
Baseline:(2013) MACs M&E capacity limited and 32 MACs M&E assessed. No organized means of reporting
Baseline:(2013) Draft M&E and capacity building plans developed
Baseline:(2014) NIM Toolkit produced and NIM trainings workshops held, for sustainability, NIM training needs to be institutionalized through LIPA
Output 2: Baseline: (2014) 50 percent
Baseline: (2013)1 private sector engagement meeting held
Baseline: (2011) Draft NGO policy in place
Baseline: (1998) NGO database created
Baseline: (2013/2014) 2 Trainings already conducted
Output 4: Baseline: (2014) New functional areas for hired Directors and Assistant Directors under the newly created LRA and MFDP
Baseline: (2014) No IT strategy in place; Data center under construction by UNDP; It team currently has one vehicle
Output 5: Baseline: (2014) Social-economic data is available but needs to be updated
Baseline: (2014) Economic papers are written but no regular economic journals produced
Output 6:
Baselines: 1. Limited publicity of UNDP’s contribution to development (source: ADR report) 2. Draft partnership and communication strategy in place

Output 1: NIM Toolkit launch 25 procurement staff 2 RBM Training 30 M&E reports 150 Manuals 1 NIM training curriculum and training modules
Output 2:
3 Private sector meetings 2 Civil society meetings NGO policy NGO Database 6 trainings (80% male, 20% women)
Output 4: 10 Directors 25 Assistant Directors LRA Data Center MFDP strategic Plan
Output 5: 1 Social –economic report 2 Economic journals

Deepening of National Implementation policies and business processes skills of 74 staff from 23 SET IPs and RPs conducted and participants benefited from practical orientation on the use of the NIM Toolkit.
NIM Toolkit launched and NIM Toolkit training curriculum and training modules draft developed by the Liberia Institute of Public Administration (LIPA) for short term refresher/orientation training of national partners. LDSP used NIM Toolkit for NIM training of their implementing agencies.
LRA Data Center established and equipped for effective and efficient of tax revenue collection.
PPCC Hands-on Facility and Toll free Call center established to enhance the public procurement system by improving upon the existing capacity of public procurement practitioners, thereby allowing for increased proficiency and efficiency in the delivery of the entities’ core mandates and strategic plans, as well as in the achievement of the Government’s national development priorities as set forth in the Agenda for Transformation (AfT).
MFDP strategic plan produced and 300 printed
54 MFDP staff members comprising of Directors, Assistant Directors and Senior Analyst from benefited from a RBM Training specifically tailored to enhance skills to deliver the 3 year Strategic Plan.
62 (42 males & 20 females) Planning and Budgeting officers, and M&E officers from 20 MACs RBM knowledge and skills capacities were improved through training.
82 (26 Female and 56 Male) key Sub-national level development actors from 15 county comprising of 15 County Superintendents, Assistant Superintendents for Fiscal Affairs, Assistant Superintendents for Development, and Regional Development Officers underwent through an orientation program on fiscal and development planning.

Output 1 60 Male & 20 Female possess skills to develop procurement specs, TOR and Concept Paper 55 Male and 15 Female possess RBM skills Zero draft PBM&E Guide
Output 2 AfT Mid-Term meeting V20130 documents Annual Aid Report
Output 3 180 Trained in CIPS Level 2 45 Trained in CIPS Level 3 50 CIPS Certified MACs procurement staff
Output 4 RIA heavy duty baggage Scanners Domestic Resource Mobilization Strategy Fraud and risk management strategy LRA Tax strategy and analysis Real Estate Cadastre
Output 5 National Domestication Liberia Action Plan for SDG implementation 2014 MDG report 2015 NHDR report AEC Outcome document
Output 6 Media platforms media stories Quarterly reports 2016 Annual report

description.narrative: The project provides support to security institutions in 8 border counties to support enhanced border management and surveillance in response to EVD and small arms proliferation.

title.narrative: Emergency Support to National Response to EVD
Emergency Support to National Response to EVD
Emergency Support to National Response to EVD

description.narrative: support to enhancement of border for EVD surveillance
policy, planning and administration

Fully equip at least 720 officers and men of the BIN and LNP to fight Ebola and maintain law and order;Cover at least 1000 EVD training for security management and other officials covering 8 counties;provide social safety net support to at least 4000 EVD affected persons in the 8 counties.

comment.narrative: Limited capability of BIN and the LNP to undertake EVD related responsibilities of quarantining communities, providing escort/protection to healthcare workers and healthcare facilities, supervising burials of victims and ensuring enhanced border surveillance within the context of the Ebola response.
fully equip 1,000 BIN and LNP operatives with state of the art communication equipment and mobility in all official border points
